Now after a 'execution' James has to get out alive of the people he gave swirilies and wedgies to in highschool. They are out on a vendetta and guess who was behind it! Gary from Bullworth academy!

One of the most underrated titles from Rockstar Games. Manhunt is a brutal stealth game that heavily relies on the player to execute their enemies by sneaking up from behind. At the time, the game's premise and tone were unique for being quite depressing and brooding, causing massive controversies that continued with the release of its sequel, Manhunt 2. Yet inside of Manhunt's nihilist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t was a solid stealth/action game that directly engages and intimidates you. The only massive problem with Manhunt is its age, with its primitive cover and shooting mechanics, yet they are easy to adapt to after playing for a while. Even if you're not interested in Manhunt's gameplay, it's perfectly acceptable to own it as a piece of history, when video games were significantly pushing the envelope on the portrayal of violence. Whether you like it or not, Manhunt is one of the most important games of the last decade, and owning a copy is highly recommended.

There is much to be said about manhunt. If you do not already know, this game was surrounded by tons of controversy, this is the singular game your soccer mom does not want you to play. If you do not know the story behind the controversy, grab a drink and get comfortable, because this is a long and interesting story. When the game was first released, nobody really paid much attention to the game, critics gave it mixed reviews and the game almost fell into the category of overlooked. But of course this did not happen, on July 28th 2004 14 year old Stefan Pakeerah had been brutally murdered by his best friend Warren Leblanc. Now, when something like this happens, we as humans go through what I call a “moral panic”, meaning when we have been wronged in some way it is so much easier for us to find a boogie-man to pin all of our problems on, so that way we don’t have to take responsibility for these tragic actions. And in this case Leblanc’s parents had their own moral panic and rather take responsibility for not noticing their kids dwindling mental stability, they found their sons copy of Manhunt, a perfect boogie-man to go to court with. Fortunately the 50 million pound (or 81,156,500 dollar) lawsuit was dropped, however the controversy never went away and has since then followed Rockstar Studios to this day.  Now on to the game itself. The gameplay is very violent, and you will be murdering in systematic and unique ways. Honestly, in my opinion, it’s really not that bad. There are so many other violent and brutal games out there that make this game look like Super Smash Bros. in comparison. It is a stealth based game so you will learn to work on baiting your enemies into a trap where you will slowly pick them off 1 by 1, engaging head-on will get you absolutely nowhere. The AI can be a bit frustrating with their dead on aiming and their ninja reflexes, but bear in mind this is a very old game and the AI is very simplistic by our standards. Don’t let that be a turn off, the plotline mysterious and ominous.  Overall I would highly recommend this game to anybody who is looking for a fun and plot oriented action game. This game really did not deserve all the controversy it received and I think it’s a real jewel that has slowly faded out of the spotlight.

Before I begin, this game is NOT for the faint of heart. If you are squeamish, offended easily, or even get scared easily, then this is NOT the game for you.  --  Rockstar's most controversial game is right here. Its dated and its gritty as ♥♥♥♥, but its pretty groundbreaking for 2003. Its almost a shame that this game that this game was so underrated and scrutinized by some of the world's scummiest politically correct politicians.  Now, let's get to gameplay. This game is very frightening in the fact that while you're given the option to fight the opposing scumbags, but not only will you get your ♥♥♥ kicked harder than a queer at a jhock convention, but it is also more rewarding to take them on from the shadows. Its not until you're armed with guns that you'll feel secure taking on the hordes of low life ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s out to hunt you down.  The executions in this game are also pretty damn rough. Even though many games now have begun to feature some pretty gruesome things, this game was 2003, and the executions you can deliver to your enemies can range from harsh to ♥♥♥♥ing brutal. And not to mention that you can blow people's brains out quite literally with a shotgun.  But what's most intriguing about this game is that there is a story behind it as you progress. What this story is about and why you're out killing various nut jobs... well, that's for you to find out.  All in all, this game is well rounded for what it is. It has some rough spots, and it needs a little work to get the game up and running (especially if you don't have XP), but it'll be a well made purchase if you like horror survival. Hell, this game has made me jump a few times, and I don't scare easily. Five Nights At Freddy's, eat your heart out.  7.5/10 - A diamond in the rough.

Manhunt is all sorts of things -- an idea about control and the lack of it; about the diminishing sense of identity in our growing world of high-level security; about the rampant level of violence in our culture, and the sick dependence we have for seeing said violence on TV. Yes, it's about all sorts of things. Yes, indeed. But the core of Manhunt is about listening. Listening, reacting to your environment, and adapting. It's essentially the jail-bound, drug-taking step-child to the TV show Survivor, except you're not kicked off the island. You're hunted down and bludgeoned to death -- for fun, entertainment and, because in some strange way, it's sexy.
Despite NECESSARY patching and a complete lack of support from Rockstar, the game remains a unique experience which accurately brings the feeling of a slasher movie to a video game.
